commander.name: Generale di Divisione Luigi Sibille
commander.previous_service: Commanded division from formation until capture December 11, 1940. Became POW with division.

personnel_at_destruction.note: All personnel became prisoners of war December 11, 1940

supply_logistics.supply_status: UNIT DESTROYED - Division captured December 10-11, 1940 during Operation Compass. All supplies (fuel, ammunition, water, food) captured by British Western Desert Force at Maktila camp. Q1 1941 represents post-destruction status - division did NOT exist as functional unit during January-March 1941.
supply_logistics.notes: Division had 2 days fuel, 10 days ammunition, 3 days water at time of capture December 10-11, 1940. All stocks captured by British forces.

temperature_range_c.notes: Winter desert conditions at former Maktila camp location (division no longer exists)

weather_environment.terrain_type: Desert plateau - Maktila area, Western Desert, Egypt (former division position)
weather_environment.notes: Environmental data for Q1 1941 NOT APPLICABLE - division destroyed December 11, 1940 and did not exist during Q1 1941. Data represents conditions at former Maktila camp position.

medical_facilities.notes: All medical facilities captured December 1940. Division medical staff became POWs.

operational_readiness.personnel_status: DESTROYED - Division captured December 10-11, 1940. Entire personnel complement became POWs.
operational_readiness.vehicle_status: CAPTURED - All vehicles captured by British Western Desert Force.
operational_readiness.equipment_status: CAPTURED - All equipment captured by British forces.
operational_readiness.recent_operations: Division destroyed during Operation Compass, Battle of Maktila, December 10-11, 1940. Division positioned at isolated Maktila camp when attacked by British Western Desert Force during sandstorm. Offered stiff resistance December 10 but disintegrated by December 11. Entire division surrendered to British Selby Force December 11, 1940.
operational_readiness.current_mission: NONE - Division ceased to exist December 11, 1940
operational_readiness.notes: CRITICAL - DIVISION DESTROYED DECEMBER 1940: 1st Libyan Division positioned at Maktila camp, farthest Italian division into Egypt (22 miles from other camps). Attacked by British Western Desert Force on December 10, 1940 during sandstorm as part of Operation Compass. Division offered stiff resistance initially but disintegrated by December 11. Entire division surrendered to Selby Force on December 11, 1940. Gen. Luigi Sibille and all personnel became prisoners of war. Division officially declared destroyed December 11, 1940. Q1 1941 represents final status at time of destruction - division did NOT exist as functional unit during Q1 1941.

subordinate_units_at_destruction.unit_designation: 1º Gruppo Fanteria Libica (1st Libyan Infantry Group)
subordinate_units_at_destruction.notes: Libyan troops with Italian officers. Captured December 11, 1940.

subordinate_units_at_destruction.unit_designation: 2º Gruppo Fanteria Libica (2nd Libyan Infantry Group)
subordinate_units_at_destruction.notes: Libyan troops with Italian officers. Captured December 11, 1940.

subordinate_units_at_destruction.unit_designation: 1º Gruppo Artiglieria Libica (1st Libyan Artillery Group)
composition: 2x Artillery batteries - 12x 77/28 Mod. 1905 each (24 guns total)
subordinate_units_at_destruction.notes: Older 77/28 field guns standard for colonial divisions. All captured December 11, 1940.
Elite Libyan paratroop battalion. 500 paratroopers organized into 4 companies. Captured December 11, 1940.

tactical_doctrine.role: UNIT DESTROYED - Colonial infantry division with Italian officers and Libyan NCOs/troops. Designed for static defense of fortified camps in Egyptian Western Desert. Part of Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940) and defensive operations at Sidi Barrani. Division destroyed December 10-11, 1940 during Operation Compass.
special_capabilities: Libyan paratroop battalion 'Fanti dell'Aria' (elite airborne unit) - CAPTURED
Adapted to desert conditions (Libyan troops native to region) - CAPTURED
Fortified camp defense tactics - FAILED December 1940
known_issues: ISOLATED POSITION: Maktila camp 22 miles from other Italian positions - enabled British to attack division in isolation
UNABLE TO SUPPORT OTHER UNITS: Distance prevented mutual support with 2nd Libyan Division at Tummar
Inferior equipment compared to regular Italian divisions (77/28 vs 75/27 guns)
Colonial troops lower training standard than metropolitan Italian troops
Poor coordination between infantry groups during British attack
Sandstorm on December 10 disrupted visibility and communications
Rapid collapse after initial resistance - morale broke quickly
UNIT DESTROYED: Division ceased to exist December 11, 1940
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Libyan troops well-adapted to desert conditions (native to region). Division trained for static defense of fortified camps rather than mobile operations. Tactical doctrine failed catastrophically when confronted by British mobile combined-arms offensive December 1940.

scenario_suitability: Operation Compass - Battle of Maktila (December 10-11, 1940) - PRIMARY SCENARIO
Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940) - capture of Sollum
Static defense of fortified camps scenario
Colonial division vs British armored/infantry combined arms
Unit destruction scenario - Italian colonial forces overwhelmed by British mobile warfare
special_rules: UNIT DESTROYED (Dec 11, 1940): Division does NOT exist in Q1 1941 - this entry represents destroyed unit status only
Historical Scenario Only: Use for December 1940 Operation Compass scenarios only
All Equipment Captured: Cannot be used for Q1 1941 scenarios - division destroyed December 1940
For December 1940 scenarios: Colonial Division (-1 training, +1 desert terrain), Isolated Position (no support), Fortified Camp (+2 defense), Sandstorm Penalty (-2 visibility Dec 10)
historical_engagements: Italian invasion of Egypt - Capture of Sollum (September 13, 1940)
Static defense at Maktila fortified camp (September-December 1940)
Operation Compass - Battle of Maktila (December 10, 1940) - DIVISION DESTROYED
Surrender to British Selby Force (December 11, 1940) - FINAL ACTION
wargaming_data.notes: WARGAMING NOTE: This unit CANNOT be used for Q1 1941 scenarios as it was destroyed December 11, 1940. Use only for Operation Compass (December 1940) historical scenarios showing division's destruction.

Web search - Libyan Paratroop Battalion 'Fanti dell'Aria' (500 paratroopers, 4 companies)
Web search - Commander Gen. Luigi Sibille confirmed (became POW December 11, 1940)
Italian colonial division TO&E (2 infantry groups, 1 artillery group, 77/28 guns)
Operation Compass order of battle (1st Libyan at Maktila, 2nd Libyan at Tummar)
Nafziger Collection 940ILAA - Battle of Sidi el Barrani December 1940
known_gaps: Infantry group and artillery group commander names not found
Exact personnel breakdown by unit uncertain (estimated from standard colonial division structure)
Precise vehicle numbers estimated from colonial division standards
Detailed battle chronology December 10-11 limited (sandstorm, confusion)
Exact number of casualties vs prisoners uncertain (all personnel became POWs)
notes: CRITICAL: Division destroyed December 10-11, 1940 during Operation Compass.
Q1 1941 listing represents DESTROYED unit status - division did NOT exist as functional unit during January-March 1941.
All equipment counts set to 0 as division was completely destroyed/captured.
Data represents division strength and organization at time of capture (December 1940).
Division formed March 1, 1940 from Italian Libyan Colonial Division.
Commanded by Gen. Luigi Sibille with 7,224 troops (Italian officers, Libyan NCOs/troops).
Positioned at Maktila camp, farthest Italian division into Egypt (22 miles from 2nd Libyan Division).
Attacked December 10, 1940 during sandstorm as first target of Operation Compass.
Offered stiff resistance but disintegrated by December 11.
Surrendered to British Selby Force December 11, 1940 - entire division became POWs.
Organization based on standard Italian colonial division (2 infantry groups, 1 artillery group, 77/28 field guns).
Included elite Libyan Paratroop Battalion 'Fanti dell'Aria' with 500 paratroopers.
Schema v3.1.0 compliant with supply_logistics and weather_environment fields (representing destroyed status).
Confidence 90% due to good sources on destruction and organization, comprehensive documentation of unit's fate.
